passages.text: August 28, 2025 11:58 PM GMT
Retail Credit Research | North America
Victoria's Secret 2Q25: Pretty, but Less Angelic for 2H

VSCO's 2Q print beat on both sales and margin, but updated guidance reflects incremental 2H margin pressure, largely the result of tariffs. While our '25 EBITDA estimates are unchanged, our outlook for 3Q & 4Q comes down post print. We stay neutral on VSCO credit given valuation vs. single- Bs.

- 2Q sales and EBITDA were ahead of expectations led by better product acceptance, international strength, lesser discounting and SG&A leverage.- Comp sales at both banners were positive in 2Q, and comps for stores and direct sales are positive on a YTD basis after marketing & brand investment.- However, management updated its expected '25 net tariff headwind to $100mn, double its prior $50mn, concentrated in the 2H25.- Our '25 sales estimate moves higher, but our Adj. EBITDA is unchanged despite the 2Q beat, moving our 2He lower and indicative of upcoming margin pressure.- We maintain a neutral view on VSCO (we closed our buy rec in May) given demonstration of a brand turnaround offset by little spread compression opportunity.

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.
Exhibit 1: Victoria's Secret & Co (VSCO) Market Levels & Total Returns (as of 08/28/25)

Credit View ( \(= \): In May, we closed our recommendation to buy the 29s (opened on September 2023) post a solid earnings print and bonds trading near all- time tights. Post 2Q, we maintain our neutral view. We think fundamentals are on the right track with turnaround momentum and a healthy balance sheet. However, bond yield is \(\sim 40bp\) inside the B- Index market (6.3% versus 6.7%) after significant outperformance since early '24. The less compelling valuation backdrop is coupled with our view that 1) rating upside is constrained (given limited banner diversity and '25 earnings headwinds), 2) EBITDA will still be down -15% in '25, despite brand traction, and 3) lingering tariff headwinds present risk to 2H earnings, leaving far few catalysts or drivers of spread compression near term.

We would rather own Bath & Body Works' (BBW) belly and long- dated bonds (we have a recommendation to buy these bonds that trade flat (on average) to VSCO despite their lesser turnaround risk, position in a better category, and lesser tariff sensitivity. We would wait for VSCO to cheapen before starting or growing a position in the credit.

Our Take on the Quarter ( \(= \): Victoria's Secret delivered solid 2Q performance, with positive comparable sales across both banners and encouraging signs of a turnaround in top- line momentum. While we are pleased to see higher sales guidance and improvement versus the prior quarter, the margin outlook was disappointing as the expected tariff headwind doubled compared to earlier guidance. 2Q adjusted operating income, while above the prior guidance range, was still down YoY, and the unchanged FY25 operating income guidance despite the higher sales guide further reflects this margin pressure. Direct sales trends were mixed—down in the quarter but slightly up for the full year—while international operations showed strength with sales up double digits. Overall, we view the sales trends as encouraging, though profitability remains pressured by the increased tariff impact.

Changes to Estimates ( \(= \): We now model FY25 revenue of\) 6.4bn, +2.2% YoY (and +2.6% vs. prior) on the 2Q sales beat and guidance that top- line strength should continue through the 2H. However, our '25E EBITDA estimate is unchanged at \$589mn (- 15.8% YoY), suggesting incremental weakness in the 2H25 vs. our prior estimates given increased tariff headwinds.
1. Sequential Sales Improvement: Net sales increased 3% to \$1.46 billion despite a digital outage in May, with comparable sales up 4%, showing sequential
improvement over the prior quarter.
2. Margins improved: Gross margin improved to \(35.6\%\) , up 20 basis points year- over-year and 60 basis points above guidance, driven by less discounting and stronger regular-priced selling.
3. International Success: International business grew \(22\%\) to \(228 million with high single-digit comparable sales across channels and particular strength in China.
4. Beauty Strength: The Beauty segment delivered its eighth consecutive quarter of growth, representing approximately \(1 billion domestically and approaching\) 2 billion globally.
5. New Customer Growth: Customer file grew \(5\%\) in July with improvements across new, existing, and reactivated customers, with notable market share gains in the 18-44 age demographic.
6. Tariff Challenges: Full-year guidance now reflects increased tariff levels of \(30\%\) for China and \(20\%\) for non-China imports, resulting in approximately \(100 million net impact for 2025.
7. Strategic Investments: The company is increasing investments in marketing and store labor to enhance customer experience and drive top-line growth.
8. Product Innovation: The Body by Victoria collection's new FlexFactor bra launch performed well, driving double-digit new customer growth.
9. Sustained Momentum: Sales momentum built steadily throughout 2Q, with July being the strongest month, and this positive trend has continued into August.
10. Inventory Optimization Opportunity: Management acknowledged opportunities to optimize inventory, particularly focusing on faster inventory turns and shortened lead times.

Operating Results (+): VSCO posted 2Q25 net sales of \(1.5bn, +3\%\) YoY and above consensus of \(1.4bn,\) while both comp & store sales were \(+4\%\) . Comps were positive at both VS and PINK, and International significantly outperformed, \(+22\%\) YoY, while Direct sales underperformed, \(-6\%\) YoY. Adj operating income of \(55mn, -11\%\) YoY, came in \(20mn\) above guidance, led by better sales and gross margin offset by higher SG&A. Gross margin expanded 20bp YoY to \(35.6\%\) (+60bp above guidance) from less discounting and better full-price selling. Adjusted SG&A rate was \(31.8\%\) , better vs. guidance of \(33\%\) but still deleveraged vs. \(31\%\) in the prior year, due to a strategic shift in marketing spend from 1Q into 2Q and higher incentive compensation expense.

FY25 Guidance (=): FY25 guidance was increased on sales and unchanged on operating income. Guidance reflects a net tariff impact of \(100mn,\) up from prior guidance of \(50mn,\) and assumes a gross impact of \(170mn\) incorporating a \(30\%\) China tariff (unch) and \(20\%\) (vs. prior \(10\%\) ) on non-China. Components of guidance are as follows: (1) Net Sales \(6.3 - 6.4bn\) (raised vs. \(6.2 - 6.3bn\) ); (2) Adj operating income of \(270 - 320mn\) (unchanged); (3) Capex \(200mn\) (lower vs. \(220mn\) ); (4) Adj FCF \(150 - 200mn\) (unchanged).

3Q25 Guidance (- ): 3Q guidance was just below expectations with key components including: (1) Net Sales \(1.39bn\) to \(1.42bn\) vs cons \(1.359bn\) ; (2) Adj operating income range of \(- 35mn\) to \(- 55mn\) vs cons \(- 41mn\) ; (3) Adj gross margin \(34\%\) vs cons \(34\%\) .

**Balance Sheet & Cash Flow (+):** Inventories ended the quarter with cash on hand of \(\) 188m\(,\) \ \(50m\) higher sequentially, and we estimate outstanding borrowings were reduced by \(-\ \(30m\) QoQ, increasing revolver availability to -\) 54Omn under its \(\) 750m\(ABL facility. Total and net leverage ended the quarter at 1.6x and 1.3x, unchanged vs. the prior quarter, respectively.
Exhibit 2: Victoria's Secret & Co (VSCO) Summary Financial Model

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next
The next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In- Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
